Is this an April Fool's thing?

So said Eric Armstrong on 4/1/2003 --------------------
Nit Patrol:
The ordering of parameters in the JUnit APIs is non-optimal
in a couple of respects.

First:
  * The message string is first in the sequence, instead of
    last. It's a huge things, but it makes it a bit harder to
    see the orthogonality in the APIs. This ordering would
    make the orthogonality more apparent:
        assertTrue(boolean)
        assertTrue(boolean, String)

    Instead, JUnit chose
        assertTrue(boolean)
        assertTrue(String, boolean)

    which is somewhat less apparent to casual observation. (I
    believe it is for that reason that adding optional parameters
    last is the normative standard.)

    More importantly, with a long string message, the assert is
    more difficult to read. Instead of this:
        assertEquals(var1, var2,
                     "some very long message down here");

    You have
        assertEquals("some very long message up here",
                      var1, var2);

Second:
  * Putting the expected results before the observed results in
    the parameter list is slightly non-optimal.

    I confess this only became apparent to me moments ago. But
    it now seems ideal to put the observed results variable ahead
    of the expected results in the parameter list.

    The reason for that is the ability to keep entries both
    adjacent and in order.

    For example, when examining this pseudo code:
        String expectedResults="...";
        [long sequence of code]
            ----top of screen---
        [more code]
        String observedResults = [results calculated above]
        assertEquals(msg, expectedResults, observedResults);

     The expectedResults setting is now far away from the observed
     results. So down at the bottom of a lengthy code sequence, it
     may no longer be obvious what it was we expected.

     On the other hand, if we code this way:
        [long sequence of code]
            ----top of screen---
        [more code]
        String expectedResults="...";
        String observedResults = [results calculated above]
        assertEquals(msg, expectedResults, observedResults);

      Now the expectedResults are where we can see them, but they
      interrupt the flow of code that produces the actual results.

      The only remaining choice is this:
        [long sequence of code]
            ----top of screen---
        [more code]
        String observedResults = [results calculated above]
        String expectedResults="...";
        assertEquals(msg, expectedResults, observedResults);

      But now the ordering is reversed from the parameter sequence.
      (A small thing, certainly, but every bit of regularity is of
       help to the beleagured brain...)

      Were the parameter ordering reversed, the code flows to
      its normal conclusion, readability is maintained, and the
      ordering of items is preserved, as well.
        [long sequence of code]
            ----top of screen---
        [more code]
        String observedResults = [results calculated above]
        String expectedResults="...";
        assertEquals(msg, observedResults, expectedResults);
